<html><head><title>Advanced HTML Tutorial - Part 1</title>
<!--Description and keywords generated by script--><meta name="description" content="Learn some of the more complex tags and code in HTML, including more text presentation options, lists, forms and image maps. (Free Webmaster Help)">
<meta name="keywords" content="html, advanced, multimedia, forms, code, examples, example, heading, div, pre, frames, tables, embed, image, map, base">
<!-- Standard Heading -->
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<script language="JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_swapImgRestore() { //v3.0
  var i,x,a=document.MM_sr; for(i=0;a&&i<a.length&&(x=a[i])&&x.oSrc;i++) x.src=x.oSrc;
}

function MM_preloadImages() { //v3.0
  var d=document; if(d.images){ if(!d.MM_p) d.MM_p=new Array();
    var i,j=d.MM_p.length,a=MM_preloadImages.arguments; for(i=0; i<a.length; i++)
    if (a[i].indexOf("#")!=0){ d.MM_p[j]=new Image; d.MM_p[j++].src=a[i];}}
}

function MM_findObj(n, d) { //v4.0
  var p,i,x;  if(!d) d=document; if((p=n.indexOf("?"))>0&&parent.frames.length) {
    d=parent.frames[n.substring(p+1)].document; n=n.substring(0,p);}
  if(!(x=d[n])&&d.all) x=d.all[n]; for (i=0;!x&&i<d.forms.length;i++) x=d.forms[i][n];
  for(i=0;!x&&d.layers&&i<d.layers.length;i++) x=MM_findObj(n,d.layers[i].document);
  if(!x && document.getElementById) x=document.getElementById(n); return x;
}

function MM_swapImage() { //v3.0
  var i,j=0,x,a=MM_swapImage.arguments; document.MM_sr=new Array; for(i=0;i<(a.length-2);i+=3)
   if ((x=MM_findObj(a[i]))!=null){document.MM_sr[j++]=x; if(!x.oSrc) x.oSrc=x.src; x.src=a[i+2];}
}
//-->
</script>

            			<!-- Page Title -->
                       <p align="center"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="5"><b><font color="#000099" size="6">
                       Advanced HTML Tutorial<br>
              <font size="4" color="#000000">Part 1 - Advanced Text Formatting</font></font></b></font></p>

              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Advanced Text Formatting</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/2">Part 2 - Lists, Headings & Base</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/3">Part 3 - Forms</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/4">Part 4 - Further Forms</a></li></ul></font>

              <!-- Page Content -->
              <p><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2">
              <div align="right" style="float:right">
<iframe src="http://rcm.amazon.com/e/cm?t=freewebmaster-20&o=1&p=14&l=st1&mode=books&search=html reference&fc1=000000&lt1=&lc1=3366FF&bg1=FFFFFF&f=ifr" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" width="160" height="600" border="0" frameborder="0" style="border:none;" scrolling="no"></iframe>
</div><font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Introduction</b></big></font><br />
<br />
HTML is made up of a great many elements, a lot of which are overlooked, forgotten or just unknown to many web designers. Although with a basic knowledge of HTML you can develop a website, to take advantage of many of the advanced features, and to make pages fully compatible, it is useful to learn these less popular tags.<br />
<br />
Before reading this tutorial, you should have a basic idea of how HTML pages work, and how to do basic coding in HTML. A good reference for this sort of thing is the HTML Basics Tutorial, here on Free Webmaster Help.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>More &lt;font&gt;</b></big></font><br />
<br />
The font tag is the most used HTML tag, and takes a very basic form. It allows you to specify the color, size and font of text. Although largely thought to be obsolete by many developers, due to the greater control given by stylesheets, it still provides a very easy way to change the look of the page.<br />
<br />
The basic use of the font tag involves setting a font using:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;font face=&quot;Arial&quot;&gt;Text&lt;/font&gt;<br />
</font><br />
but this does introduce another problem, that of different computers accessing a page. Unlike publishing methods such as print, it is up to the user&#039;s computer, not the printer, to render the pages, so they can look different on all computers. This is especially noticable with the font face attribute, as it is very rare to have a font installed on every computer that visits a website. Because of this the HTML specification has a system built in where multiple fonts can be specified. For example, you can use:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;font face=&quot;Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif&quot;&gt;<br />
</font><br />
which would tell the browser to first try to display the text in Arial, if that wasn&#039;t found try Helvetica and if not use the standard sans-serif font. This allows you to have  control over how pages are displayed by browsers without the correct font, although it is far from perfect. The best uses for this tag, are if you really want to use a non-standard font (and don&#039;t want to use stylesheets) or if it is important that you can accurately predict how pages will look on other computers. It is good practice to use font face in this way for all applications, though, for the sake of compatibility.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Bold, Italic, Underline and Strikethrogh</b></big></font><br />
<br />
A further method of controlling how your text appears, other than changing the size color and font is to apply the four standard text formats to it. HTML has tags for all of these, which are supported by nearly all browsers.<br />
<br />
Bold text is simple to create, it uses either the:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;b&gt;Text&lt;/b&gt;<br />
</font><br />
or<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;strong&gt;Text&lt;/strong&gt;<br />
</font><br />
tags. Usually, it is simply a matter of preference over which one you choose, but accessibility experts normally recommend using &lt;strong&gt; as many screen readers (programs which read web pages to the blind) will recognise that the text is highlighted and speak it appropriately.<br />
<br />
Similarly you can create text in italics using:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;i&gt;Text&lt;/i&gt;<br />
</font><br />
or<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;em&gt;Text&lt;/em&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Again, it really doesn&#039;t matter whether you choose to use &lt;em&gt; or &lt;i&gt;, but screen readers can often recognise &lt;em&gt; and emphasised text.<br />
<br />
Underlines are achieved using:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;u&gt;Text&lt;/u&gt;<br />
</font><br />
although I would recommend against using this greatly, as it can often be confused with links on the page. Strikethrough, is used to &#039;cross out&#039; text:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;strike&gt;Text&lt;/strike&gt;<br />
</font><br />
although this is not particularly commonly used.<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Subscript and Superscript</b></big></font><br />
<br />
Subscript and superscript (text slightly above or below the line) is something which has long been supported, but is not common as it is only commonly used in scientific applications. There are other uses, though, and it is not a difficult tag to implement:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
8 x 8 = 8&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;<br />
</font><br />
8 x 8 = 8<sup>2</sup><br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
H&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;O<br />
</font><br />
H<sub>2<<br />
/sub>O<br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Preformatted Text</b></big></font><br />
<br />
HTML has been designed so that it ignores multiple spaces in documents, for example if you enter two standard spaces it is rendered as one. Although this allows indentation of code without changes to the presentation on screen, it does make it difficult to display some sorts of content (such as pre-formatted tables written in plain text). For this, you can use the &lt;pre&gt; tag. This stands for preformatted text, and will display the text exactly as it appears in the document source, for example:<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#0000FF"><br />
&lt;pre&gt;<br />
<pre><br />
Name           Location         Sales<br />
----           --------         -----<br />
A. Name        London           1,000<br />
A. Nother      Washington       2,000<br />
A. Person      Paris            2,400<br />
</pre><br />
&lt;/pre&gt;<br />
</font><br />
Without the &lt;pre&gt; tags this would display as:<br />
<br />
Name           Location         Sales<br />
----           --------         -----<br />
A. Name        London           1,000<br />
A. Nother      Washington       2,000<br />
A. Person      Paris            2,400<br />
<br />
but after adding the tags in it shows up as:<br />
<br />
<pre><br />
Name           Location         Sales<br />
----           --------         -----<br />
A. Name        London           1,000<br />
A. Nother      Washington       2,000<br />
A. Person      Paris            2,400<br />
</pre><br />
<br />
<font face="Arial" color="#000099"><big><b>Part 2</b></big></font><br />
<br />
In part 2 I will show you how to create lists in HTML and also the standard heading tags.</font></p>

              <!-- Bottom Navigation -->
              <table width="100%" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2" border="0">
              <tr>
              
              
              
              <!-- Links To Other Tutorial Parts -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top"><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul><li><b>Part 1 - Advanced Text Formatting</b></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/2">Part 2 - Lists, Headings & Base</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/3">Part 3 - Forms</a></li><li><a href="http://www.freewebmasterhelp.com/tutorials/html-advanced/4">Part 4 - Further Forms</a></li></ul></font></p></td>
              
              <!-- Related Links -->
              <td width="50%" valign="top">
              <font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif" size="2"><ul>

</td>

			 <!-- End Bottom Navigation -->
			 </tr></table>
